question: Why is a defined-head boundary represented as a horizontal line in a Q–h plot? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! In Dirichlet conditions, head is fixed; Q varies. It often reflects external controls like rivers.
error: ❌ Not quite. Remember: it's the head that is fixed, not the flow.

question: Which characteristics best describe a head-dependent boundary (Robin condition)? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! Head-dependent flux is based on the head difference times a conductance value.
error: ❌ Incorrect. Only when heads are equal is the flow zero — not always.

question: What happens in the model if recharge is increased while keeping boundary types unchanged? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! Recharge increases head and thus outflow, but aquifer properties and boundary locations stay the same.
error: ❌ Not quite. Recharge affects system input and outflow, but it does not alter aquifer properties or boundary positions.

question: In which of the following cases does the Q–h plot appear as a vertical line? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! Neumann (defined-flow) boundaries have fixed Q, so the Q–h plot is vertical.
error: ❌ Not quite. Vertical Q–h lines occur when flow is fixed regardless of head — typical for no-flow and recharge.

question: Which statements correctly describe the influence of hydraulic conductivity (K) in the 1D model? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! K determines how easily water flows through the aquifer, affecting both head gradients and total discharge, but not the Q–h shape at a fixed-head boundary.
error: ❌ Not quite. K strongly influences both head gradients and discharge, but it does not affect the Q–h curve shape at a Dirichlet boundary.

question: In a 1D model with recharge and a no-flow boundary, which of the following are true? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! No-flow boundaries force one-directional flow; recharge raises head, but no flow occurs at the boundary.
error: ❌ Not quite. Q–h at no-flow is vertical (Q = 0, variable h), and no head-dependent exchange occurs there.
